In this article I will explain how to pragmatically retrieve the stats (number of claps and comments)  of any Medium post using a custom‚Ä¶

Post:5d377e02d5d9.title: The missing part of Medium‚Äôs REST API

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_1.name: f10d
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_1.text: The missing part of Medium‚Äôs REST API

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_2.name: 44aa
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_2.text: In this article I will explain how to programmatically retrieve the stats (number of claps and comments) of any Medium post using a custom REST API, the lack of this feature in the official Medium REST API is what motivated me to create this custom REST API.

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_3.name: d9bf
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_3.text: First, let‚Äôs see the documentation of the official public REST API by Medium.

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_4.name: caaf
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_4.text: When it comes to articles (posts), The official Medium API only provides an HTTP POST method to create a Medium article (cf section 3.3), you can not edit or retrieve an article using the official REST API üò•, I don‚Äôt really know why Medium staff has decided not to implement such a useful feature, but it‚Äôs certainly a regretting design choice.

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_5.name: 5f70
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_5.text: While working on a personal project, I needed to retrieve the stats (number of claps and comments) of my Medium posts within a reasonable response time, I looked everywhere to find a solution to my needs but I couldn‚Äôt find it, so I had no choice but coding it by my self.

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_6.name: 6c36
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_6.text: My first intuition was to look at the official REST API but no such feature is provided, then I looked at the RSS feed by Medium and nothing was there neither, after that I started inspecting Medium using Chrome‚Äôs DevTools in order to understand how the stats are retrieved then displayed under a Medium story.

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_8.name: f393
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_8.text: Surprisingly, among all the XHR requests there was no request to retrieve the stats üòÆ, which led me to look at the HTML response of the article page.

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_12.name: c83f
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_12.text: We notice that the number of claps and comments are directly injected in the HTML response as a javascript variable, we can verify that by taping console.log(window.__APOLLO_STATE__); in the Javascript console of the Post page.

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_13.name: 39d8
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_13.text: The content of the window.__APOLLO_STATE__ object

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_14.text: Now that we found where the stats are available at, we only need to parse the HTML page and look for the two tokens containing the number of claps and comments which are clapCount and responsesCount .

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_15.name: d1ae
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_15.text: How to use the custom API :

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_16.text: You can use the custom API that I built right now as follows:

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_21.text: The API responds within [500, 1500] ms which is pretty reasonable knowing that the API starts by sending an HTTP request to Medium then it parses the response before returning the stats to the requester.

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_22.name: b114
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_22.text: The API is Open Source we welcome any kind of contribution, if you find this post interesting let a comment and hit the üëè button below.

Paragraph:834ca27adf44_24.name: 41aa
Paragraph:834ca27adf44_24.text:
Medium/medium-api-docs
This repository contains the documentation for Medium 's API. Medium's API is a JSON-based OAuth2 API. All requests are‚Ä¶github.com
